interval). The slope of the one-to-one line is indistinguishable from the line of best fit in terms of correlation
suggesting there is no consistent bias in the method. Standard deviation of inferred values with respect to the
one-to-one line is ~22% of the mean change. This provides an estimate of the uncertainty of our method (i.e.
using parameterized equation (1) to infer water cycle change).
We have now established that equation (1), with mixing timescales inferred from historical/pre-industrial
balances, represents a robust relationship between water cycle change and salinity distribution change. Using
from these data with the method uncertainty (see Methods) we estimate a change in
0.025 Sv for CSIRO between 1950 and 2010. Considering the climato-
logical mean water cycle obtained from the re-analysis/observational data, these changes imply an amplification
of the water cycle (i.e. defined as the water cycle change inferred from equation (1) divided by the climatological
Figure 4b shows the change in water cycle amplitude versus the global-mean surface air temperature change
for the ten CMIP5 models in their historical (1950–2005), RCP4.5 (2006–2100), and RCP8.5 (2006–2100) runs.
Results indicate a robust relationship between increasing water cycle amplitude and surface warming. The linear
trend (R~0.87, statistically significant at the 99% confidence interval) gives a water cycle amplitude sensitivity to
2.0%/°C for CMIP5, which is much less than that predicted by the Clausius-Clapeyron relation-
°C). The observationally inferred water cycle change versus global surface temperature change over
for CSIRO, sits within the spread of CMIP5 models (4.3
and observations are consistent in terms of their oceanic water cycle response to a given amount of global surface
warming, within the large uncertainties of each.
Our estimate of water cycle sensitivity to warming based on our CMIP5 ensemble (~4.3%/°C) is very close to
based on the CMIP3 ensemble of E-P PA (~4.5%/°C). It is interesting to note that in
is increasing at a significantly lower rates (~3.4%/°C, Allen and Ingram
- than the global E-P pattern (~4.5%/°C, Durack

change versus inferred water cycle change using equation (1) based on changes in the mean salinity deviation.
